channel.title: All In The Mind - Program podcast
channel.itunes:subtitle: All In The Mind is Radio National's weekly foray into the mental universe, the mind, brain and behaviour - everything from addiction to artificial intelligence.
channel.description: All In The Mind is Radio National's weekly foray into the mental universe, the mind, brain and behaviour - everything from addiction to artificial intelligence.

channel.itunes:author: ABC Radio National
channel.itunes:summary: All In The Mind is Radio National's weekly foray into the mental universe, the mind, brain and behaviour - everything from addiction to artificial intelligence.

item.title: Behind the Shock Machine
item.itunes:subtitle: In 1961 Stanley Milgram conducted a controversial series of experiments which were said to show that we're all capable of evil in certain circumstances. Many of the participants are still traumatised. This is a panel discussion about the lessons and ethics of these experiments..
item.description: In 1961 Stanley Milgram conducted a controversial series of experiments which were said to show that we're all capable of evil in certain circumstances. Many of the participants are still traumatised. This is a panel discussion about the lessons and ethics of these experiments..
item.itunes:author: Lynne Malcolm

item.title: Remembering together
item.itunes:subtitle: We feel we should be able to recall all sorts of things at will—but how often do our individual memories fail us? As part of a study on social memory, a group of cognitive psychologists and philosophers heard the shared histories of long term married couples to investigate how they combine their memories. The strategies they use could help people with dementia.
item.description: We feel we should be able to recall all sorts of things at will—but how often do our individual memories fail us? As part of a study on social memory, a group of cognitive psychologists and philosophers heard the shared histories of long term married couples to investigate how they combine their memories. The strategies they use could help people with dementia.
item.itunes:author: Lynne Malcolm
item.itunes:keywords: memory, social memory, extended mind, dementia

item.title: The Creating Brain: reaching Xanadu
item.itunes:subtitle: Is there anything different about the brains of extraordinary creative geniuses like Michelangelo, Coleridge or Mozart?
item.description: Is there anything different about the brains of extraordinary creative geniuses like Michelangelo, Coleridge or Mozart? World renowned psychiatrist and doctor of English Renaissance Literature Dr Nancy Andreasen unravels the 'creative brain' and explores how we can foster creativity in ourselves and throughout our society.
item.itunes:author: Lynne Malcolm
item.itunes:keywords: psychology, creativity, intelligence, mental illness, schizophrenia, depression, Coleridge, Kubla Khan, Neuroscience, brain, Lynne Malcolm, Nancy Andreasen, art, literature

item.title: A history of memory
item.itunes:subtitle: For centuries scientists have grappled with the concept of memory—what is it, how does it work and can we really rely on it? US historian Alison Winter traces the history of the way we have conceptualised memory—from the use of truth serums and hypnotism to the science of forgetting. She describes the way memory has been compared to filing cabinets, flashbulbs and motion pictures over the past century.
item.description: For centuries scientists have grappled with the concept of memory—what is it, how does it work and can we really rely on it? US historian Alison Winter traces the history of the way we have conceptualised memory—from the use of truth serums and hypnotism to the science of forgetting. She describes the way memory has been compared to filing cabinets, flashbulbs and motion pictures over the past century.
item.itunes:author: Lynne Malcolm
item.itunes:keywords: memory, hypnotism, truth serums, Bridey Murphy, memory wars, post traumatic stress disorder

item.title: Our emotional brain
item.itunes:subtitle: Pioneering neuroscientist Richard Davidson deepens our understanding of the mind-body connection. He’s identified six unique emotional styles and explains the brain chemistry underlying them. He explains that there are simple strategies and interventions which we can use to change our emotional styles. He believes one effective example is through mindfulness meditation, after studying the brain scans of people who practise it.
item.description: Pioneering neuroscientist Richard Davidson deepens our understanding of the mind-body connection. He’s identified six unique emotional styles and explains the brain chemistry underlying them. He explains that there are simple strategies and interventions which we can use to change our emotional styles. He believes one effective example is through mindfulness meditation, after studying the brain scans of people who practise it.
item.itunes:author: Lynne Malcolm

item.title: I hurt myself: the secrecy of self harm
item.itunes:subtitle: According to a large study on self injury conducted in 2008 by the University of Queensland, 220,000 Australians injured themselves deliberately, without meaning to suicide, in the month prior to the survey. For some people, hurting themselves is a way of coping with overwhelming psychological pain. In this program we hear about what mental processes go on behind this behaviour and we hear from a young woman who openly shares her experience of self injury in order to educate health workers about the best ways to treat people like her.
item.description: According to a large study on self injury conducted in 2008 by the University of Queensland, 220,000 Australians injured themselves deliberately, without meaning to suicide, in the month prior to the survey. For some people, hurting themselves is a way of coping with overwhelming psychological pain. In this program we hear about what mental processes go on behind this behaviour and we hear from a young woman who openly shares her experience of self injury in order to educate health workers about the best ways to treat people like her.
item.itunes:author: Lynne Malcolm

item.title: Orchids, dandelions and an intriguing set of genes
item.itunes:subtitle: Are you a sensitive flower -- like a vulnerable orchid, or more like a hardy dandelion? We explore the intriguing orchid–dandelion hypothesis which suggests that the genes that underlie our greatest weakness may also be the basis for our most positive traits, given the right environment.
item.description: Are you a sensitive flower -- like a vulnerable orchid, or more like a hardy dandelion? We explore the intriguing orchid–dandelion hypothesis which suggests that the genes that underlie our greatest weakness may also be the basis for our most positive traits, given the right environment.
item.itunes:author: Lynne Malcolm

item.title: All in the Mind 10th Anniversary Special 7: The Marco Polo of Neuroscience - V.S Ramachandran
item.itunes:subtitle: Natasha Mitchell has interviewed many of the world’s most celebrated thinkers on the mind over the past decade, and one the most creative is acclaimed neuroscientist and polymath of the brain Professor V.S Ramachandran. Next week, All in the Mind swaps shows and slots for a season of an exciting new show The Body Sphere hosted by Amanda Smith. In April, All in the Mind returns for a season, presented by Lynne Malcolm. Body and mind hook up on ABC Radio National! 5pm Sundays, 1pm Mondays. Natasha Mitchell will now be hosting our national daily program Life Matters each weekday morning.
item.description: Natasha Mitchell has interviewed many of the world’s most celebrated thinkers on the mind over the past decade, and one the most creative is acclaimed neuroscientist and polymath of the brain Professor V.S Ramachandran. Next week, All in the Mind swaps shows and slots for a season of an exciting new show The Body Sphere hosted by Amanda Smith. In April, All in the Mind returns for a season, presented by Lynne Malcolm. Body and mind hook up on ABC Radio National! 5pm Sundays, 1pm Mondays. Natasha Mitchell will now be hosting our national daily program Life Matters each weekday morning.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell
item.itunes:keywords: psychology, robotics, artificial intelligence, A.I, Noel Sharkey, Ronald Arkin, Colin Allen, war, military, autonomous agents, ethics, philosophy, morality, behaviour, intelligence, human rights, privacy, warfare

item.title: All in the Mind 10th Anniversary Special 6: The Power of Forgiveness
item.itunes:subtitle: Psychologist Pumla Gobodo-Madikizela was on South Africa's historic Truth and Reconciliation Commission, chairing many of its tortuous public hearings about atrocities committed in the apartheid era. In an unprecedented dialogue she met with one of apartheid's most abhorrent killers, in jail, to explore forgiveness, psychological redemption and the symbolic language of trauma.
item.description: Psychologist Pumla Gobodo-Madikizela was on South Africa's historic Truth and Reconciliation Commission, chairing many of its tortuous public hearings about atrocities committed in the apartheid era. In an unprecedented dialogue she met with one of apartheid's most abhorrent killers, in jail, to explore forgiveness, psychological redemption and the symbolic language of trauma.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell
item.itunes:keywords: psychology, robotics, artificial intelligence, A.I, Noel Sharkey, Ronald Arkin, Colin Allen, war, military, autonomous agents, ethics, philosophy, morality, behaviour, intelligence, human rights, privacy

item.title: All in the Mind 10th Anniversary Special 5: The Banyan
item.itunes:subtitle: All in the Mind is turning 10, and over the decade we've taken you across the globe to discover how the mind and its discontents are profoundly shaped by culture. A chance to meet again the incredible women of The Banyan in India - with stories of triumph amongst the deepest despair.
item.description: All in the Mind is turning 10, and over the decade we've taken you across the globe to discover how the mind and its discontents are profoundly shaped by culture. A chance to meet again the incredible women of The Banyan in India - with stories of triumph amongst the deepest despair.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: All in the Mind 10th Anniversary Special 4: Brave New Brain
item.itunes:subtitle: Celebrate All in the Mind's tenth birthday! Over the decade the show has tracked some of the provocative technological developments and ethical debates about our state of mind. From stem cell therapy to the spectre of animal-human chimeras or cyborgian selves...we love to get heady and technical!
item.description: Celebrate All in the Mind's tenth birthday! Over the decade the show has tracked some of the provocative technological developments and ethical debates about our state of mind. From stem cell therapy to the spectre of animal-human chimeras or cyborgian selves...we love to get heady and technical!
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: All in the Mind 10th Anniversary Special 3: Getting Personal
item.itunes:subtitle: As All in the Mind turns 10, we're digging into the archives to get personal. It's a celebration of the neuro-narrative. Meet Electroboy, poet Sandy Jeffs...encounter a brain surgery and be moved by stories of life, loss and love.
item.description: As All in the Mind turns 10, we're digging into the archives to get personal. It's a celebration of the neuro-narrative. Meet Electroboy, poet Sandy Jeffs...encounter a brain surgery and be moved by stories of life, loss and love.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: All in the Mind 10th Anniversary Special 2: Are You Conscious?
item.itunes:subtitle: All in the Mind started with Zombies back in 2002...not of the Day of the Living Dead kind, but the philosophical variety! Celebrate All in the Mind's 10th birthday with us. This week, Natasha revisits the great conundrum of human consciousness with leading thinkers - it's a problem that continues to stump the brightest minds.
item.description: All in the Mind started with Zombies back in 2002...not of the Day of the Living Dead kind, but the philosophical variety! Celebrate All in the Mind's 10th birthday with us. This week, Natasha revisits the great conundrum of human consciousness with leading thinkers - it's a problem that continues to stump the brightest minds.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: All in the Mind 10th Anniversary Special 1: Getting Sexy
item.itunes:subtitle: It's 10 years since Natasha Mitchell started All in the Mind and we're digging into the archives for you! This week, getting sexy in true adolescent spirit - the perplexing case of the female orgasm, getting your kicks in a brain scanner, and is the sex between your ears more important than the sex between your legs!
item.description: It's 10 years since Natasha Mitchell started All in the Mind and we're digging into the archives for you! This week, getting sexy in true adolescent spirit - the perplexing case of the female orgasm, getting your kicks in a brain scanner, and is the sex between your ears more important than the sex between your legs!?
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Mind the gap! The seduction of the synapse
item.itunes:subtitle: Bah! All that talk about brain cells and grey matter!  Let’s focus on where the real interesting action is inside your head: the connections between your brain cells—synapses. From the ancient past to the frenzied future—it's all about making connections.
item.description: Bah! All that talk about brain cells and grey matter! Let’s focus on where the real interesting action is inside your head: the connections between your brain cells—synapses. From the ancient past to the frenzied future—it's all about making connections.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell
item.itunes:keywords: brain, mind, behaviour, neuroscience, Seth Grant, Geoff Goodhill, Huda Akil, Natasha Mitchell, synapses, neural engineering, evolution, science, neural networks, mathematics, modelling

item.title: A personal tour: Sigmund Freud's Vienna
item.itunes:subtitle: In the 50 years before he emigrated to escape the Nazis, Sigmund Freud, his wife Martha and six children lived and worked in the house at Berggasse 19 in Vienna.
item.description: In the 50 years before he emigrated to escape the Nazis, Sigmund Freud, his wife Martha and six children lived and worked in the house at Berggasse 19 in Vienna. His most famous works were penned there, his most famous patients bared their 'souls' there. Join Natasha Mitchell for a personal tour through the archives of the Fin de Siecle mind.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell
item.itunes:keywords: psychology, mind, brain, behaviour, Sigmund Freud, Carl Jung, Sigmund Freud Museum, Vienna, Austria, science, neuroscience, Anna O, Albert Einstein, Marie Bonaparte, Natasha Mitchell, Anna Freud, Josef Breuer, mental health, A Most Dangerous Method

item.title: The case for moral enhancement - 2011 Adelaide Festival of Ideas
item.itunes:subtitle: Oxford-based, Australian bioethicist Julian Savulescu is a provocateur.
item.description: Oxford-based, Australian bioethicist Julian Savulescu is a provocateur. He's argued the case for a 'new eugenics' and that we have a moral obligation to pursue human perfection. Now he thinks we should be using science and technology for moral enhancement itself. Could the future of humanity depend on it?
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell
item.itunes:keywords: psychology, ethics, enhancement, cognitive enhancement, Julian Savulescu, Natasha Mitchell, bioethics, morality, moral enhancement, genetics, science, technology, Adelaide Festival of Ideas

item.title: Loneliness: breaking the taboo
item.itunes:subtitle: Loneliness has been with Emily White for as long as she can remember.
item.description: Loneliness has been with Emily White for as long as she can remember. Smart, savvy, popular - none of this has inoculated her against 'the ghost in her life'. Her memoir is an encounter with the emerging, powerful science of loneliness, and a taboo like few.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell
item.itunes:keywords: psychology, mind, brain, mental health, Emily White, Lonely, solitude, loneliness, depression, society, social networks, behaviour, alone, science, health, community

item.title: Practice makes perfect?
item.itunes:subtitle: The virtuoso violinist, star surgeon and super sportswoman - could any of us become the best of the best?
item.description: The virtuoso violinist, star surgeon and super sportswoman - could any of us become the best of the best? Daniel Coyle toured the world's famous talent 'hotbeds' in search of secrets. Psychologist K. Anders Ericsson says with enough 'deliberate practice' - 10,000 hours of it, he argues - anything's possible. But does that trump 'natural talent'?
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell
item.itunes:keywords: psychology, Dan Coyle, The Talent Code, K. Anders Ericsson, myelin, neuroscience, brain, sport, expert, athletes, musicians, expertise, mind, talent, performance, education, training, learning, Maria Tickle, deliberate practice
